prompt:
We have the following datasets. One of the dataset contains CpG methylation values per CpG and per individual as a table this is contained in the “metRmOlWithDbgapIdHeader.txt” file. Each column is an individual represented by a DBGapId, which is included as the first row. Each row is a CpG represented by "CpG_id", values in the table are methylation values. Another data set is contained in “subjects.txt”. This file has the information on the individuals. Most important feature for us here are the "Age","sex" and "Race" columns. The "dbGap ID" column (second column) in this table should match the first row of the "metRmOlWithDbgapIdHeader.txt", and they represent the same individuals. Find all CpGs associated with Age but not with sex or Race, and display top 20 CpGs.

response:
This error can be resolved by using the `check.names=T` argument in `read.delim`. This is because the function treats names with spaces as syntactical names and escapes them.

Let's modify the code to fix the error.

```
# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(readr)

# Load you data
methylation_data <- read_delim('metRmOlWithDbgapIdHeader.txt', delim="\t", col_names=TRUE, check.names=T)

methylation_data <- as.data.frame(t(methylation_data), stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
names(methylation_data) <- methylation_data[1, ]
methylation_data <- methylation_data[-1, ]

subject_data <- read_delim('subjects.txt', delim="\t", col_names=TRUE)

# Merge the data frames
combined_data <- left_join(subject_data, methylation_data, by = c("dbGaP ID" = "V1"))

# Change numeric columns to numeric type
numeric_columns <- names(combined_data)[sapply(combined_data, is.character)]
combined_data[, numeric_columns] <- lapply(combined_data[, numeric_columns], as.numeric)

# Run a linear regression for each CpG, selecting the ones associated with age but not with sex and race
results <- sapply(combined_data[5:ncol(combined_data)], function(cpg) {
  model <- lm(formula = paste(cpg, "~ Age + sex + Race"), data = combined_data)
  age_p_val = coef(summary(model))["Age", "Pr(>|t|)"]
  sex_p_val = coef(summary(model))["sexM", "Pr(>|t|)"]
  race_p_val = coef(summary(model))["Race", "Pr(>|t|)"]
  return(c("Age" = age_p_val, "Sex" = sex_p_val, "Race" = race_p_val))
})

# Create a table with results
results_table = t(results)
results_table = as.data.frame(results_table)

# Filter to CpGs associated to age but not sex and race
cpG_age_related = results_table %>% filter(Age < 0.05, Sex > 0.05, Race > 0.05)

# Display the top 20 CpGs
top_20_cpGs = head(cpG_age_related[order(cpG_age_related$Age), ], 20)
```

This code will load the data, preprocess it, run a multiple linear regression model for each CpG site, and then select the top 20 CpG sites which are more associated to age than to sex and race based on p-values. You might need to adjust the p-value cut-off based on your specific use case.
